title: 109_hr4481
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Superfund for Hurricane Accountability and Recovery Act of 2005". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 established a Federal Superfund trust fund for hazardous substance remediation, with over 45,900 sites evaluated and 1,540 Superfund sites on the National Priorities List. More than 70,000,000 Americans live near a Superfund site, and funding shortfalls have impacted new construction funding for sites in recent years. The Congress finds that receiving new construction funding in fiscal years 2004 and 2005 slowed the pace of existing cleanups, delaying and magnifying public health risks. The reestablishment of the Superfund tax would not affect the liability of responsible parties for hazardous substance releases. Hurricanes Katrina and Rita caused unprecedented environmental damage in the Gulf Coast States, leading to significant new releases of hazardous substances and damage to 54 listed sites. The Congress acknowledges the environmental damage caused by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita in the Gulf Coast States, resulting in new releases of hazardous substances and damage to 54 listed sites. It emphasizes the need for the removal, remediation, and cleanup of hazardous substances to protect public health and mitigate environmental damage, with costs to be borne by responsible parties. SEC. 3. SUPERFUND TAXES. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to Hazardous Substance Superfund financing rates and corporate environmental income tax for specific taxable years. Technical amendments are also mentioned. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to Hazardous Substance Superfund financing rates and corporate environmental income tax for specific taxable years. Technical amendments are also made to sections related to crude oil exports. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include a temporary rate increase to fund hurricanes Katrina and Rita toxic waste cleanup. The tax specified for certain chemicals and imported substances will be increased by 50% during the period from January 1, 2006, to December 31, 2008. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include a temporary rate increase to fund hurricanes Katrina and Rita toxic waste cleanup. This involves a temporary increase in corporate environmental income tax from January 1, 2006, to December 31, 2008, with a specific percentage adjustment. Additionally, a separate accounting for cleanup funds is established through the creation of a Gulf Hurricanes Cleanup Account within the Hazardous Substance Superfund. The Hazardous Substance Superfund establishes the Gulf Hurricanes Cleanup Account to receive transfers from appropriated amounts under specific tax increases. The Gulf Hurricanes Cleanup Account receives transfers from tax increases under the Hazardous Substance Superfund for expenditures in accordance with the Superfund for Hurricane Accountability and Recovery Act of 2005. Unexpended funds revert to the Hazardous Substance Superfund by December 31, 2009, or upon the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's determination under the Act. Effective Dates:
- Excise taxes amendments (except paragraph 2) and certain income tax amendments take effect upon enactment of the Act.
- Income tax amendments for specific subsections apply to taxable years starting after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. EXPENDITURES FROM TRUST FUND.

Funds in the Gulf Hurricanes Cleanup Account are designated for addressing hazardous substance releases caused by Hurricane Katrina or Rita until the EPA determines no further action is needed. The Administrator must notify Congress before initiating any rulemaking.

SEC. 5. CLEANUP REPORTS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency must provide Congress with an annual report on the progress of cleanup activities for Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. The report should include details such as personnel allocated, major contracts awarded, contaminated sites identified, and stages of cleanup process completion. The annual report to Congress on cleanup activities for Hurricanes Katrina and Rita must include details on identified sites, contaminants discovered, extent of contamination, emergency removals, remedial actions taken, expenditure of funds, estimated costs, and completion dates for necessary response actions.
